text:
<metadata theme-color="red" />

<question>
  When we found a bug in our program,
  what is the most import thing to remember?

  <answer>
    Don't panic.
  </answer>
</question>

<question>
  What is a bug?

  <answer>
    A bug is the difference between
    the expected behavior of the program
    and the observed behavior of the program.
  </answer>
</question>

<question>
  How to debug?

  <answer>
    (1) Clearly express the observed behavior.

    (2) Clearly express the expected behavior.

    (3) Guess what causes the difference and put the guess into test.

    Don't panic. Be a scientist. Use logic.
  </answer>
</question>

<question>
  When we are guessing the cause of the difference,
  what is the most import thing to remember?

  <answer>
    All differences are caused by something.
  </answer>
</question>

<question>
  What is the cause of an effect?

  <answer>
    The cause of an effect is an attribute (or an aspect) of a model,
    when we change it the effect will change because of it.
  </answer>
</question>

<question>
  What is a model?

  <answer>
    All cause must be understand in the context of a model.

    (See Judea Pearl's book "Causality -- Models, Reasoning, and Inference".)

    When trying to find the cause of a bug, our program is the model.
  </answer>
</question>
